But I am led to oppose their views by the authority of a very reliable man3 for the poet Sophocles asserts that it isa poisonous, as does Simos also among the physicians‚ saying that the juice of the decocted or pounded plant, when poured upon the body, produces the same sensations of burning as those felt by persons bitten by a serpent, when this plant is applied to the wound. LXXXIX. Thyme ought to be gathered while it is in blossom‚ and to be dried in the shade. There are two kinds of thymet--one white, with a wood- like root, growing on hills and also the inore highly valued3 the other kind is darker and with a dark flower. Both kinds are supposed to be very bene- ficial for brightening the vision, whether taken as food or used in medicines, also for a clu-onie eough, to ease expectoration when used as an electuary with vinegar and salt, to prevent the blood from eongealing when taken with honey, to relieve, applied externally with mustard‚ chronic catarrh of the throat, and also complaints of the stomach and bowels.
